advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ALTAIR CONVENTION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Altair Convention was here announced in the Computer Notes magazine.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> NASCOM 1 BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>1983 Hannover show advert. <br><br> Advert said that 30,000 Kaypro II systems were already sold in the U.S.A.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Better features, cheaper price, the PC price war has just started.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the competition is dumb !"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mci.org.br" target="_blank">Museu da Computação e Informática - MCI</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORIGINAL ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The history of the Galaksija started with a magazine article - called "Raèunara u vašoj kuæi" (computers in your home) by Dejan Ristanoviæ. This magazine was the first issue of the magazine series called later "Raèunara". This first issue included an article about the do-if-yourself computer "Galaksija" written by Voja Antonic. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source : <a href="http://www.homecomputer.de/" target="_blank">HomeComputerMuseum.de</a></font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OEMS WANTED</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICRO7 COVERPAGE (SEPT. 84)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Micro7 was a french computing magazine in the 80's. In september 84, its first page was featuring the EXl-100.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PICTURE (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture was used for promoting Educatel, a French private computing school.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FROM WALKMAN TO M5</strong></font><br><blockquote>This US dealer advert says that the designer of the M5, Toshiaki Kamijo was before the Walkman inventor in Sony CIE.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The computing answer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOFTCARD COPY</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert for one of the numerous copies of the Microsoft SotfCard. Initially, they were manufactured in the United States then in Asia. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>"There music puts in it"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMIGA POSTERS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPACT VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>Promotional picture; <br><br> <b>Diego Barizo</b> adds:<br> In the picture of the compact version of the TK3000, the joystick, a TRS-80 de luxe joystick, and the screen is quite similar to that of a flight simulator for the TRS-CoCo. Maybe they had one behind the monitor? <p class="petitgris">Roberto Isiri</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIL ORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Computer assisted mail-order <br><br> As soon as the home computers could communicate easily through modem with large computer sites, the major mail-order companies had the idea to sell products to the computers users. This concept was facilitated in France by the free distribution of the 'Minitel' Videotex terminal that was gradually integrated into home computers. The success gained by this system in France did not have any equal in the rest of the world. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The major argument of the advert campaign was "we have a better and cheaper computer than Apple and IBM"...<br><br> True, but like many other computers of the time, the major fault of the Advantage was not to be an IBM system...</blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: NS-HUBASIC V1.0, V2.0A, V2.1 or V3.0
computer.description:
This is an initiation computer. It was sold as an add-on for the Japanese Famicom (but can't be connected to a NES as it lacks the Famicom's Expantion Port).
In fact the system is composed of three parts : the Famicom, the keyboard and the Basic cartidge. The keyboard is connected to the expansion port situated at the front of the Famicom. Then a Basic cartridge must be inserted into the Famicom catridge slot. As the keyboard is almost "empty", most of the Famicom's hardware is used, along with the Basic cartridge RAM chips.
The Basic delivered with the keyboard is the NS-HUBASIC, where "N" stands for Nintendo, "S" for Sharp and "HU" for Hudson, as they all contributed to this project. Once inserted there is only 1982 bytes free to play with ! But it was possible to back-up the program into the cartridge itself by powering it with 3 battery cells. This saving method wasn't reliable as quite often the programs were lost because of bad contacts... Hopefully, a tape-recorder was available, but there again, the adjustment of the input level was quite difficult to get.
Some games using the built-in save/load feature of the Basic cartridge were released such as "Lode Runner" (edit mode) and "Challenge Race".
The catalog number of the keyboard is HVC-007.
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard with functions keys and arrow keys
computer.language: NS-HUBASIC V1.0, V2.0A, V2.1 or V3.0
computer.name: Family Computer Keyboard
computer.peripherals: Expansion memory unit, tape-recorder, Basic cartidges
computer.ram: Basic V2.0A : 1982 bytes freeBasic V3.0 : 4086 bytes free

computer.sound: 5 channel sound (2 channels for square wave, 1 triangle wave, 1 noise channel and 1 PCM)
